To date, there is convincing evidence that Mars once had microbial life forms. There is absolutely no evidence that flora and fauna developed on Mars like on Earth. None. The spinning toroid artificial gravity machine that would be necessary would have to be enormous and the cost to get such a machine out of Earth's atmosphere would make the whole thing financially impossible.


Humans would have to first build a base on the Moon, build machines that could extract what little water is on the moon and convert it to rocket fuel, and then build an artificial gravity machine that could keep the astronauts alive. And we haven't even covered habitat, the amount of water astronauts would have to carry with them, the dangers of space debris, etc. Too many obstacles. Maybe in the year 2080-2100. That is....if humans survive that long. Mars is a pipe dream and a waste of money that should be spent fighting climate change.

If you read this, Hi Derek, great video, as always. I'd just like to point out one little thing you said at the end of the video : "We don't have the rock record from when life was first evolving on this planet". That is, actually, not entirely true, the primordial material coming from asteroids and comets which aggregated in the early stage of the formation of Earth is believed to be pretty much the same material we are seeing on asteroids and comets today and while the Stardust mission collected some of the micrometeorites coming from those celestial bodies in 2006, we can actually find these kind of micrometeorites here on Earth. Obviously we can only find such micrometeorites in the most isolated places of our planet but it's doable and it is absolutely done. I actually work (as an intern, I'm still a student) with the "Laboratoire d'Astrophysique du Solide" in Orsay, France which is actively  gathering such micrometeorites in Antarctica and The Arctic and then studying them with Focused Ion Beam in Orsay. In the last few years, organic material has been observed in those micrometeorites and this is one of the many research helping us to understand the origin of life on Earth. Anyway, always happy to see Science being shared :)

I don't understand the purpose of sending a rover to collect samples for POSSIBLE future return to Earth after being collected by humans on Mars. First of all, there's no concrete plan to send humans to Mars, so those samples may very well sit there with the rover forever and never be picked up. Secondly, what's the difference between sending a rover to collect samples and sit around with them until humans come get them and just sending humans to collect those same samples and bring them back themselves? Answer: the cost of that rover. It's a waste. Humans can drill chalk sized samples too, and it's not like they're time sensitive. It's not "oh, we gotta get a rover there to lock down those samples before they go bad on Mars!" No. Those same samples will be sitting in the same place if/when humans get there. They're not going anywhere; nobody's there to move them.

An interesting trivia connection... In the 1970's, my father was a photographer for the Smithsonian Institution. On July 1, 1976, he was assigned, along with several other Smithsonian photographers,  to take photos of the inauguration ceremony of the National Air and Space Museum. For the ceremony, the Smithsonian had been given (or loaned not sure which, but eventually given) one of the testing duplicates of the Viking Mars lander. They had set it up on the front entrance area of the building and someone had fitted the sampling arm with a pair of scissors  on the end. As the speeches began, some official pushed a button which sent a signal (through Nasa's network) to the Viking lander which had just landed on the surface of Mars. The lander waited a specified length of time then sent a signal back to its duplicate on Earth, triggering the arm, which then proceeded to reach out and cut the dedication ribbon, just as the speeches came to an end.

Tardigrades are a really poor example of the kind of organism we should worry about contaminating Mars. Yes, they can survive being in space, but only when in cryptobiosis. So assuming they somehow ended on a craft, they would have to go into cryptobiosis in order to survive the journey, and they need a good reason to do that. Last time I checked spacecrafts aren't permanently kept in ultra dry, freezing, and/or anoxic environments, and once they enter space, it's highly unlikely they would be able to enter cryptobiosis fast enough.
Even if we ignore all of that, once they are on Mars, what exactly do you expect them to do? They need oxygen, food, and liquid water to be active and reproduce. Not things that Mars has a lot, if any, of. They are gonna be stuck in their cryptobiotic state accumulating damage, until they become unable to come back to life again.

I actually work in a cubicle that makes the parts that help the rovers communicate with earth. We have wave guide switches on every NASA mission for the past 40 years, every vessel at sea, and every missile manufactured by raytheon and any 7-11 where you use a credit/debit card reader. SCIENCE!

I agree that if we want a definitive answer about life on Mars we'll need to return samples. It would be vastly expensive and hugely complicated to bring the sort of lab technology to the surface of Mars and have a rover do the sort of testing that can be done on Earth in a fraction of the time with 1000x the accuracy. There's a picture floating around that shows just how far the rovers have traveled and the farthest rover has only traveled the distance a human could theoretically travel in a single day. That just shows how imperative it is we push to get a space lab to Mars and figure out how to get humans to survive the journey. There's just certain things that humans can do at a much faster frequency with a higher precision. However I don't think risking humans to the interplanetary radiation and prolonged exposure to microgravity is worth finding out if life existed on Mars. Make it safe first and foremost.
